snippet.title: Family's timber was pivotal in Nambour's development
snippet.content: FROM the 1890s, Nambour was defined by the imposing presence of the sugar mill - its impressive black chimney, piercing steam whistle and sweet full-bodied aromas invoking local residents' senses with a persistent reminder of its all-encompassing influence. That the mill laid claim to the town was a truth difficult to ignore. Currie St, part of the Bruce Hwy and Nambour's main thoroughfare, hosted the majority of the sugar town's retail businesses. They were strung out, fringing the ribbon of road streaming down Church Hill to the Petrie Creek bridge. The mill interrupted this smooth flow with its main cane tram line cutting across Currie St, neatly slicing its retail centre into four pieces. The compass bearings of the four corners helped Nambour residents identify local retail stores by using each quadrant's premier landmark, be it Bayard's Corner, The Bank of New South Wales, The Royal George or The Club Hotel. Local retailers were unperturbed by the mill's apparent imposition as to a large extent their own livelihoods were dependent on its continued prosperity. The sugar industry attracted a range of supporting industries directly and indirectly. As Nambour's population grew, all that was needed to provide comfortable amenity for the population grew with it. Early pioneer Walter Lanham, my great-grandfather, identified business opportunities developing in the fledgling community, as did a number of his contemporaries such as the Whalleys, Curries, Burys and Lows. The town's business fathers - energetic, civic-minded and purposeful - earnestly set about creating a prosperous town by building successful businesses. Establishing a steam-driven sawmill in Price St in 1910, Walter and his sons set about producing sawn timber for the boom in domestic and business construction. Success was evident as the town grew and prospered so that by the 1940s, the sawmill relocated from the town's centre, opposite the railway station, into a Court Rd location known as Frog's Hollow. Here it steadily re-invented itself from the roughneck Lanham's Sawmill into a modern retail timber and hardware store set up to keep pace with the changing demands of a new millenium. Its evolution reflected the changing face of Currie St's retail businesses adapting, disappearing or being superceded in change after change. Eventually, even the imposing Moreton Central Sugar Mill fell victim to the winds of change. Its closure irrevocably uprooted any implied lingering vestiges relating to its commercial ownership of the town. Nambour's current business challenges lie not in doggedly regaining what has been lost but in confidently seizing the phenomenal opportunities for growth. The reinvention of its future naturally builds upon the solid and resourceful foundations laid by its founding fathers. Perhaps it's a new day awaiting the energetic, civic-minded and purposeful community leaders to again rise and shine.
